docs.lead_paragraph: The proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, mostly because of reductions in poverty among black and Hispanic families, the Census Bureau reported today. The data reflected three consecutive years of growth in income, which have restored household incomes and poverty to the levels recorded in 1989, just before the last recession.

headline.main: Black and Hispanic Poverty Falls, Reducing Overall Rate for Nation

docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports that proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, mostly because of reductions in poverty among black and Hispanic families; data reflects three consecutive years of growth in income, which have restored household incomes and poverty to levels recorded in 1989, just before last recession; poverty rate is 13.3 percent in 1997, down from 13.7 percent in 1996 and 15.1 percent in 1993; number of people in poverty, 35.6 million last year, has dropped by 3.7 million since 1993; poverty rate for non-Hispanic whites is unchanged at 8.6 percent last year; rate for blacks declines to 26.5 percent, lowest since Govt began collecting data on poverty among African Americans in 1959; poverty rate for Hispanic Americans declines to 27.1 percent, from 29.4 percent in 1996 (M)
docs.snippet: The proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, mostly because of reductions in poverty among black and Hispanic families, the Census Bureau reported today.    The data reflected three consecutive years of growth in income, which...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report (Science Times, Sept. 22) that some English doctors are agreeing to do elective Caesarean sections to avoid malpractice lawsuits in the event that something goes wrong in a vaginal birth. A Caesarean section is not only more expensive, but it is also not natural. (Evolution would have gone in another direction if vaginal delivery were not superior.)
docs.abstract: Katherine Stoecklin letter says it is acceptable for women to have elective Caesarean sections that have no medical justification as long as insurance companies do not have to pay for them (Sept 22 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to reignite her flagging campaign to unseat Gov. John G. Rowland, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly began her long-delayed television campaign today as the two met in the first of a series of back-to-back, head-to-head appearances. With the start of Mrs. Kennelly's ads, Connecticut television viewers are being given the candidates' conflicting views on regulating health-maintenance organizations. But the onslaught will be somewhat unbalanced. Mr. Rowland, a Republican, has spent about $180,000 for 10 days of television ads, while Mrs. Kennelly, a Democrat, plans to spend about $70,000 for the same length of time, on stations that would include some cable outlets in the Connecticut suburbs of New York.

headline.main: Rowland's Opponent, Trailing In Polls, Begins TV Campaign

docs.abstract: Rep Barbara B Kennelly, trying to reignite her flagging campaign to unseat Connecticut Gov John G Rowland, begins her long-delayed television campaign; Rowland has spent about $180,000 for 10 days of television ads, while Kennelly plans to spend about $70,000; Kennelly and Rowland photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The former chief financial officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to 18 months in jail after being convicted of trying to block a Senate investigation into the insurance company's financial problems, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan announced. The former executive, Jerry Weissman, was convicted in March 1997 of filing false reports to a Senate subcommittee and of obstructing its investigation into Empire, which, with more than 4.4 million customers, is New York State's largest health insurer.

headline.main: Ex-Officer of Blue Cross Is Sentenced to Jail

docs.abstract: Jerry Weissman, former chief financial officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, is sentenced in Federal District Court, Manhattan, to 18 months in jail after being convicted of trying to block Senate investigation into insurance company's financial problems (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In payback for Gov. George E. Pataki's budget vetoes last spring, the New York City teachers' union -- one of the state's most potent political operations -- endorsed his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone, yesterday. Mr. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, trails in the polls and desperately needs the phone bank and direct-mail operations -- to say nothing of the votes -- of the 133,000-member United Federation of Teachers, which bills itself as the nation's largest union local in any field. Most of the state's powerful and traditionally Democratic labor unions, convinced that Mr. Pataki is a cinch for re-election, have decided to sit out this race, depriving Mr. Vallone of much of the organizational support on which he was counting.
docs.abstract: United Federation of Teachers, New York City's teachers' union, endorses Democratic gubernatorial candidate Peter F Vallone, in payback for Gov George E Pataki's budget vetoes last spring; Pataki signs children's health bill at Mount Sinai Medical Center; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER I look at my bank statement, I think of Ken Hakuta, a.k.a. Dr. Fad. Best known as the inventor of the Wacky Wall Walker, he made some $20 million from slime-covered plastic creatures that ooze down vertical surfaces. The beauty of it is that Mr. Hakuta didn't even come up with the idea: all he did was license the toy from Japan for a fraction of the amount he made. Now he's a millionaire and a prominent figure on the lecture and convention circuits. With one simple idea he achieved the American dream: money and fame. There are countless Ken Hakutas -- inventors of the pet rock, sliced bread, the rolling lint remover, the better mousetrap. And I want to be one. But I'm too busy writing articles like this one to follow up on any get-rich-quick schemes, and I can't seem to put the energy into starting a corporation dedicated to carrying out my ideas. So I have decided to give them away.

headline.main: Want Some Million-Dollar Ideas? I Got a Million of 'Em

docs.abstract: Neil Strauss offers some humorous ideas for starting a new business, such as 'undating' service that specializes in breaking up relationships, a portable baby sitting service, and an expensive car ferry service traversing Hudson River; drawing (Special secion on entrepreneurs)

docs.lead_paragraph: CHRYSTAL SOFTWARE'S document-processing products were born at the Xerox Corporation, but they sure did not fit there. Xerox can take years to develop a line of copiers; software goes stale in months. And Xerox thinks in terms of billion-dollar businesses. Even R. Steven Kiser, Chrystal's president, concedes that if Chrystal is wildly successful this year, its sales will not top $15 million. ''We're not even a blip on Xerox's radar screen,'' Mr. Kiser said. ''If we were still part of Xerox, we'd be killed off.'' So why does Chrystal exist? Because two years ago, Xerox started a New Enterprises division whose sole purpose is to keep promising products from falling through corporate cracks. The group spun out Chrystal as a separate company, which Xerox expects to take public next year.

headline.main: When a Big Company Hatches a Lot of Little Ideas

docs.abstract: Corporate America, once considered anathema to all things entrepreneurial, is becoming a birthing ground for start-up businesses; often, big companies let fledgling firms buy into their benefits programs, use their lawyers and other support staff and drop their name with customers; but the small companies manage their own budgets, design their own compensation plans and live or die by their own decisions; example cited of giant Xerox Corp, which two years ago started a New Enterprises division, whose sole purpose is to keep promising products from falling through corporate cracks; group spun out Chrystal Software as a separate company, which Xerox expects to take public next year; drawing (Special section on entrepreneurship in America) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN as children, many of them spotted a business angle nobody else did, and milked it for all it was worth. At age 10, Harold S. Blue, now the chairman of Proxymed Inc., a health-care information-services company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., figured he could make more money if he hired playmates to shovel driveways instead of doing the work himself. He paid them $3 of the $5 he collected and even had the presence of mind to ply his trade outside his neighborhood so that the mothers wouldn't catch on to his scheme.

headline.main: Their Businesses May Be Small, But Their Ambitions Rarely Are

docs.abstract: Personality characteristics of entrepreneurs discussed; not every successful business owner can boast of an early flair for salesmanship; but even those who drifted or were pushed into entrepreneurial careers seem to have natural bent for seizing opportunities that make competitors wonder why they didn't think of that themselves; for most entrepreneurs, it all begins with realization that working for somebody else just isn't a choice; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The financially ailing HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, has been placed under state supervision in an attempt to improve its fiscal standing. The Acting State Insurance Commissioner, Jaynee LaVecchia, said on Monday that regulators are now overseeing virtually every aspect of HIP's financial operations and that a state-appointed supervisor will oversee day-to-day operations.
